sect1.title: Impact of Sex/Gender, Culture, Race, Age, and Other Aspects of Diversity
sect1.para: Ageism is a sociocultural and interpersonal influence that must be considered when interviewing older adults. It is well-established that ageism (defined as age-related stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination) has adverse effects on the physical and mental health of older adults, worsening chronic health conditions and memory, and increasing rates of depression and hospitalizations (Allen et al., 2022 ). Ageist Ageist attitudes can be implicit or explicit and come in many forms in healthcare, including use of “elderspeak,” (e. g., talking to an older adult as if they are a child, oversimplifying information), assumptions about lack of independence, ignoring sexual health needs, or dismissing/underestimating health concerns. Clinicians working with older adults should take active steps to reduce ageism in their encounters, address and change approach when ageism occurs (e. g., in the form of an age-related microaggression), and advocate for their older adult patients when ageism is apparent across a healthcare team or setting.

Race and ethnicity can have unique unique impacts on the aging process, with specific challenges experienced by minoritized racial and ethnic older adults (Trinh et al., 2019 ). Racial and ethnic older adult populations often face health and healthcare disparities, including higher rates of unaddressed physical and mental health conditions and limited access to inclusive and quality services (Forrester et al., 2020 ; Jimenez et al., 2022 ). Such disparities have been shown to be influenced by minority stress factors, including discrimination across a lifetime, bias in institutions and clinicians, and income inequities (Lavingia et al., 2020 ).

The provision of an inclusive and culturally competent interview and related feedback should also consider cultural context around well-being and beliefs about mental health. For example, recent cross-cultural surveys illustrate that the relation of positive affect to age across the life-cycle varies markedly by world region and culture (Helliwell et al., 2024 ). In terms of beliefs about mental health, studies have found a common belief among Black, Asian, and Latinx older adult groups in the United States that mental illness originates from familial disruption (Jimenez et al., 2022 ). For Asian Americans and Latinx older older adults, this notion may be linked to migration and relocation, which can shape cultural dynamics and exert a profound impact on health perspectives and beliefs. Intergenerational and extended family support can significantly impact well-being, and the family environment can provide valuable context for understanding symptoms and functioning. It is thus imperative for clinicians to be mindful of racialized disparities in care, cross-cultural differences in influences on mental health, and ensure conclusions are holistically informed and culturally contextualized.

Older adults who hold a minoritized gender and/or sexual orientation are also likely to face significant mental health and healthcare disparities. LGBTQ+ individuals are a rapidly growing segment of the older adult population, yet remain vulnerable to experienced and anticipated forms of discrimination, victimization with violence, microaggressions, and internalized cisheternormativity (Fredriksen-Goldsen et al., 2014 ; Preston, 2024 ). LGBTQ+ racial and ethnic minority older adults in particular experience exclusion, isolation, and diminished social support within the LGBTQ+ community, due due to the dominance of a White and youth-focused culture (Chen et al., 2022 ). Similarly, trans LGBTQ older adults face a myriad of unique concerns with aging. Data from the Trans Metlife Survey on Later-Life Preparedness and Perceptions in Transgender-Identified Individuals, one of the largest databases of its kind, has illustrated that trans people of color and those living with disability have many concerns regarding aging, including anticipated discrimination, loss of control, and poor quality of life, particularly related to receipt or not of gender affirming care (Walker et al., 2023 ). Overall, studies have shown that many LGBTQ+ people experience fears of anticipated mistreatment or marginalization as they age, particularly with regard to institutions or providers being biased and non-inclusive (Casanova-Perez et al., 2021 ). Clinicians conducting diagnostic interviewing should also be aware of the unique stressors that may be faced by minoritized individuals and consider this in conclusions and recommendations.

sect2.title: Sociocultural Considerations in Diagnostic Interviewing
sect2.para: The diverse health health and aging needs of older adults can be addressed through cultural competency and cultural humility practices and training of healthcare professionals to reduce stigma and discrimination to practice practice effective healthcare. Cultural competence Cultural competence can involve gaining knowledge about the needs, experiences, and preferences of particular communities a clinician is likely to encounter. While greater knowledge of a particular group can help to increase understanding of certain experiences, including discrimination and victimization, it is important to avoid stereotyping and consider intersecting identities that contribute to unique individualized experiences of older adults (Trinh et al., 2019 ). In some ways, this very chapter could be considered as having a framing of cultural competence in describing the unique considerations for conducting interviews with older adults broadly. This approach has been critiqued for obscuring intersectionality and implying that a clinician can reach a level of “knowing” about a given community or cultural group. Thus, cultural humility cultural humility , an ongoing process of clinicians reflecting on on their own identities, values, and biases and how these impact, intersect, and interact with patient identities and experiences (Tervalon & Murray-García, 1998 ), is also necessary. The combination of these approaches to multicultural practice can offer an approach to mitigating disparities experienced by older adults in mental healthcare, at least on a clinician level (Greene-Moton & Minkler, 2020 ). In establishing rapport with patients via empathy and openness, it is also essential to ensure that language barriers are addressed to facilitate communication. Language difficulties between patients and providers can lead to inaccurate and inadequate evaluations and misdiagnosis and further contribute to healthcare disparities (Llorente & Valverde, 2019 ); thus, interpretation through bilingual staff, medical interpreters, qualified translators, friends and family members, and telephone/telehealth interpreter services may assist the interview process. Further, organizations, hospitals, and healthcare settings should work at an institutional level to increase recruitment and retention of diverse clinicians clinicians and uphold cultural competency competency trainings (Greene-Moton & Minkler, 2020 ).
